Ring my bell

THE GOOD LOVER

By Lisa Harris
Directed by Floyd Rumohr
Chekhov Theatre Ensemble
Producer's Club II
616 9th Ave. (279-1858)
Equity showcase (closes March 21)
Review by Adam Cooper

Too few productions feature a female playwright and honestly attempt to explore women's issues. Lisa Harris, who starred in and wrote her own one-woman show, attempts to address this void. With an impatient lover waiting outside her bathroom, frustrated Lisa conducts a journey of self-exploration guided by her lack of ever experiencing an orgasm. Through soliloquy and role-playing, she relives and examines her romantic and sexual experiences, gaining insight and self-acceptance. The production was entertaining but ultimately fell short of a satisfying experience.

Lisa wants to be a good lover. She has insecurities about her body, fears of abandonment, and difficulties functioning sexually. She examines relationships with an assortment of men. There was popular Charlie, an early boyfriend with whom all was new and exciting. Later, there's a so-called boyfriend with whom sex was "a lot of work," who dumped her for sex elsewhere. And there was a Navy man with whom she had a terrifying experience. She interviews men to unlock the magic ingredient for attraction, which she discovers is being "nice." This leads her to explore what common relationship verbiage like "being nice," "having a boyfriend," and "fucking" really mean.

She relates dialogue about sexual experiences: alienating sex talk with her father, sex education from a seasoned counselor at Bible camp, or various therapies - which include "practicing" (masturbation), lengthy self-examination before a mirror, and a rewarding trip to a sex-toy shop. Well into adulthood, she has difficulty using a prophylactic device, has experienced many years of celibacy, and fakes orgasm without knowing what one is really like.

While there was wide episodic coverage of her sensual life, what was presented was largely incomplete and unresolved snippets of experience. Their incompleteness made Lisa's character changes seem unreal, resulting in a metamorphosis both unearned and artificial. Organic connections were needed to unify the different phases of Lisa's life. Ultimately what's required is a better-defined, dramatically evolving character. Without a richer characterization that goes beyond romantic and sexual encounters, Lisa's journey becomes more of a curiosity than a concern, with more complaining than confronting.

Lisa Harris's vigorous, spunky, often engaging performance (although Lisa's unsympathetic caricatures of those in her life are limiting), complemented by Floyd Rumohr's brisk direction, did much to keep the play moving and to compensate for the text's weaknesses.

What regrettably did not help was the fragmented, suggestive set (Michelle Malavet) of Lisa's bathroom. The stark crudeness of the metallic bathroom set pieces inhibited travel to the various locales on Lisa's journey. The prominent vine-like sculpture of small, irregularly shaped mirrors suggested the various Lisas explored and ironically represented the disunity of those Lisas at play's end.

The lighting (Timothy Parsaca) established the different settings but lacked subtlety. Costuming was simplistic and needed inspiration. The production had high aspirations. Hopefully with rewrites it can achieve its inspired goals.

Box Score:

Writing: 0
Directing: 1
Acting: 1
Set: 0
Costumes: 0
Lighting/Sound: 1

COWBOY CHRISTMAS

Catherine Palmer, Linda Goodnight, and Lisa Harris

Tyndale House

ISBN 0-8423-8120-1

October 2004

Inspirational

 

COWBOY CHRISTMAS is a trilogy of holiday stories set in the Old West. Christmas anthologies are very popular with readers, and this volume is sure to be no exception.

Catherine Palmer opens the book with "A Rancher's Heart." Victoria Jennings was once the pampered daughter of a rich rancher. When her father dies, his estate drowning in gambling debts, Victoria finds herself kicked out of her finishing school and selling her belongings to survive. When Victoria is reduced to fighting her employer's pigs for the choicest morsels in their slop bucket, she realizes she has no choice but to return to her foster mother, who still lives on the former Lazy J Ranch. Unfortunately, Jesse Conroy also lives there, managing the newly-christened Mesquite Land & Cattle Company. Can Jesse forgive Victoria's cavalier treatment of him in the past? Can he trust the person Victoria has become? Catherine Palmer gifts readers with a story of character shaped and tempered through adversity, and the healing powers of love and forgiveness.

In "Undercover Cowboy," Lisa Harris tells of a young woman running her crippled father's ranch. As Abby Covington fights to hold Covington Ranch together while neighboring ranches fall prey to sabotage, Cole Ramsey shows up looking for work. Unbeknownst to Abby, Cole is investigating the sabotage, and Abby's father is the prime suspect. Danger abounds, and secrets lurk in dark corners, but Ms. Harris' story glows with the light of redemption and the love of the Savior.

Linda Goodnight rounds out the trilogy with "An Outlaw's Gift." Raven Patterson has been struggling to hold her family together after the deaths of her parents. When Seth Blackstone shows up as Raven is struggling to dig a grave for her beloved dog, Raven has no idea that this man might be the embodiment of God working in mysterious ways. To thwart the local sheriff's attempts to take Raven's younger brother and sister, Seth steps forward and introduces himself as Miss Patterson's new hired hand. Soon love for Raven tempts Seth to abandon his search for the couple who ruined his life and left him a wanted man, but the need to clear his name compels Seth to pursue his quarry. Linda Goodnight's story is touching and believable, and readers will root for faith and love to overcome evil.

COWBOY CHRISTMAS is a touching holiday anthology. Readers will enjoy the personal notes from Catherine Palmer and Linda Goodnight, and each author has also included a holiday recipe for extra seasonal cheer.

 

Reviewed by Mellanie Crowther

 University of Scranton Quick Facts

Mike Strong, Head Coach


21st Season
Career Record: 484-110
.814 Winning Percentage

Mike Strong has certainly left his mark on The University of Scranton women's basketball program. 

Since taking over as head coach in 1979, he has led the Lady Royals to a record of 484-110, including an NCAA Division III national title (1985), seven Final Four appearances (1980 {AIAW}, 1985, 1987, 1993, 1997, 1999, 2000) and 17 AIAW/NCAA tournament berths.  Overall, The University of Scranton has made 20 AIAW/NCAA tournament appearances in the program's 25-year history.

A 1967 graduate of Concord College in West Virginia, Strong came to Scranton as an assistant men's basketball coach in 1972 after a successful three-year career as head basketball and head soccer coach at then Keystone College in nearby LaPlume, Pennsylvania.  He was an assistant coach when the Royals won the NCAA Division II national championship in 1976 under current head basketball coach Bob Bessoir.

Strong, who also holds master's degrees from West Chester University and The University of Scranton, is third on the NCAA Division III all-time list for coaching victories with  484 wins and is seventh in winning percentage. He has led the Lady Royals to eight straight 20-or-more win seasons and 15 times in his 20-year tenure. He has also recorded two 31-win seasons (1985, 1987) and one 30-win campaign (1993). He also serves as head coach of the Lady Royals women's tennis team and was men's tennis coach for ten years (1973-1982).

His impressive list of accolades include  the 1985 Kodak NCAA Division III Coach of the Year award and is a  three-time Middle Atlantic Conference Coach of the Year recipient (1996, 1998, 2000).  A member of the university's prestigious Wall of Fame, Strong has led the Lady Royals to an NCAA tournament-record 35 wins (against 17 losses, .673) and an overall national playoff record of 37-19 (.661).

2000-2001 Season Outlook
Mike Strong has certainly seen his share of challenges during his distinguished 20-year tenure as head coach of The University of Scranton women's basketball program.

The upcoming 2000-2001 season should be no exception.

Strong bids farewell to four letter-winners, including three starters, who led the Lady Royals to a four-year record of 103-20 (.837) and three NCAA Final Four berths.  The most notable loss is guard Kelly Halpin, the university's second-only three-time all-American and the second all-time leading scorer and career assist leader in Lady Royals' history.  Scranton will also miss guard Heather Mohrman's defensive prowess and leadership ability, center Shannon Milder's rebounding and low post presence, and center Deirdre Walsh's help off the bench in the pivot.

Despite the heavy losses, Strong can still rely on a number of key returnees to keep the Lady Royals' tradition of excellence in tact.  Two-year starter Gillian McGovern, a second-team all-MAC Freedom League selection, returns at small forward after starting all 31 games and contributing 11.5 points and 6.7 rebounds a game. Joining her on the frontline will be sophomore power forward AnneMarie Russo, the 1999-2000 Northeastern Pennsylvania Basketball Media Newcomer of the Year who started every game and led Scranton in rebounding.

Senior Lisa Harris, returning to the lineup after a one-year absence, will take over Halpin's position at the point-guard position, while fellow seniors Sarah Rooney and Jaime Eilbacher battle it out for the starting berth at off-guard.  Harris is a solid all-around performer who averaged 6.5 points, 6.0 rebounds and 3.1 assists during the Lady Royals' 28-4 and Final Four season in 1999.  Rooney and Eilbacher are long-range bombers who have the ability to spread the opposition's defense and open things up inside for McGovern and Russo.

Junior Colleen Fullerton, sophomores Amy O'Rourke and Laurel Saville, and freshman Erin Bates are just some of the candidates in line for Milder's spot at center.  Of the four, Fullerton and O'Rourke have seen the most action and could have an inside track to the position.

Another highly competitive schedule awaits the Lady Royals.  In addition to its Freedom Conference games, Scranton will take part in tournaments at the College of New Jersey and in Las Vegas.  Other non-conference games including Messiah, an NCAA tournament team in 2000, along with Ithaca and Cabrini.

Executive Committee

Region 1 (ME, VT, NH, MA, CT, RI, NY, NJ) - Christopher J. Ahmadjian

Christopher Ahmadjian, Program Manager, Baystate Roads Program-Massachusetts, UMass Transportation Center, Marston Hall 214, Amherst, MA 01003-5205; Telephone: (413) 545-2604 E-mail: ahmadjia@ecs.umass.edu

Christopher J. Ahmadjian is the Program Manager for the Baystate Roads Program (Massachusetts). Chris can be found at every training workshop from the Berkshires to the Cape. He brings great speakers, the newest technology and an emphasis on safety to the Commonwealth. When Chris is not traveling to conferences, he can be found under his cars while restoring VWs, Saabs and BMWs. Ask him anything about a VW before 1989 or a Saab before 1972. Favorite modes of transportation include a 16 valve VW GTI and a 1966 3-cylinder, 2-stroke Saab!

Region 2 (Tribal Technical Assistance Program Centers) - Evan Hong

Evan Hong, Project Director, TTAP-California-Nevada, The National Center for American Indian Enterprise Development, 11138 Valley Mall, Suite 200, El Monte, CA 91731; Telephone: (626) 350-4446; Fax: (626) 442-7115; E-mail: ehong@ncaied.org

Region 3 (PA, DE, MD, VA, WV) - Ed STellfox

Ed Stellfox, Program Manager, Maryland Technology Transfer Center, Department of Civil Engineering, University of Maryland, Myers Building 806, Suite 3102
College Park, Maryland - 20742; Telephone: (301) 403-4623; E-mail: stellfox@wam.umd.edu

Region 4 (KY, NC, TN, MS, AL, GA, SC, FL, PR) - Dr. James L. Burati

James L Burati, South Carolina Transportation Technology, Transfer Service, Civil Engineering Dept., 114 Lowry Hall, Clemson, SC 29634-0911; Telephone: (864) 656-1456; E-mail: jlbrt@clemson.edu

Jim is the Director of the South Carolina Transportation Technology Transfer Service and a Professor of Civil Engineering at Clemson University. Jim has served as the director of the LTAP Center for South Carolina, which is housed at Clemson University, since 1997. Jim has taught courses in the areas of construction management, quality management, and economic evaluation of projects for the past 22 years. His research has centered primarily in the areas of the quality and assessment of highway construction materials, and the quality management of engineering and construction operations. 

Region 5 (MN, WI, MI, IL, IN, OH) - Terry McNinch

Terry McNinch, Director, Michigan Local Technical Assistance Program, Michigan LTAP, 309 Grover C. Dillman Hall, 1400 Townsend Drive, Houghton, MI 49931-1295; Telephone: (906) 487-2102; E-mail: tlmcninc@mtu.edu

Region 6 (NM, OK, TX, AR, LA) - Marie B. Walsh

Marie B. Walsh, Director, Louisiana LTAP Technology Transfer Center, 4101 Gourrier Avenue, Baton Rouge, LA 70808-4443; Telephone: (225) 767-9117; Fax: (225) 767-9156; E-mail: mbwalsh@ltrc.lsu.edu

Region 7  (NE, IA, KS, MO) - Lisa Harris

Lisa Harris, Editor, Kansas University Transportation Center 1550 W 15th Street Room, 2011, Lawrence, KS 66045 Phone: (785) 864-2590; E-mail: LHarris@ku.edu

Lisa Harris is editor of three transportation publications--the KUTC Newsletter (LTAP), Kansas Trans Reporter (RTAP), and pc-trans magazine. She has been a member of the LTAP community since joining the Kansas LTAP in 1994. Lisa has finished  a term on the LTAP Clearinghouse Advisory Committee, where she has been liaison to the National LTAP Association's Executive Committee. While with the Clearinghouse, Lisa served on a task force to upgrade its Web site. She also has been a presenter for LTAP 101 and is helping coordinate some sessions at the 2003 meeting in Hawaii. In her spare time, Lisa serves on a boards in her community and is a contra and square dance caller and musician.

Region 8  (MT, ND, SD, UT, CO, WY) - Frank Peloubet

Frank H. Peloubet, North Dakota Transportation Technology Transfer LTAP, Center, Civil/ Industrial Eng Bldg, Rm 201H, College of Eng/Arch, Civil Eng/Construction Dept., Civil Engineering Div/ North Dakota State University, Fargo, ND 58105; Telephone: (701) 231-7051, (800) 726-4143; E-mail: Frank.Peloubet@ndsu.nodak.edu (Term 2002-2004)

Frank H. Peloubet, PE, is the North Dakota Center manager and has been with the center since 1989. His current position is that of Transportation Management Officer. Frank also teaches one or two courses each year in the Department of Civil Engineering and Construction at the University of North Dakota. He is responsible for the management and engineering services related to the centers work plan. Frank manages daily Center activities; budget preparation and control; work plan control for the satellite office; technical materials evaluation, acquisition and control; preparing and conducting training activities; review and performance of research activities; providing outreach technical assistance; technical writing support in the preparation of studies, reports, proposals, newsletter articles, etc.; and production supervision of the newsletter, publications catalog, videotape catalog, and other Center publications.

Executive Committee Meetings 2001

  • December 12, 2001

December 12, 2001

Those in attendance included: Dave Grouchy - Chair Region 6; Walt Slocomb Region 1; Mike Blankenship Region 3; Rick Smith Region 4; Terry McNinch Region 5; Duane Smith Region 7; Lisa Harris Region 7; Doyt Bolling Region 8; Bruce Drewes Region 10

  • Vendors for 2002: Mike discussed vendors for the 2002 conference. There is room for 12 vendors and the board has been asked to identify whom to invite. The board decided to charge a fee for the vendors. This seems to be a standard in the industry.
  • Points of contacts for the CBU at FHWA in DC:
    • Safety - Duane Smith and Mike Blankenship
    •  Operations - Lisa Harris
    • Infrastructure - Doyt and Terry
    • Federal Lands - Ron Hall
    • Policy - Maria and Terry
    • Resource Centers - Doyt and Mike

    Joe Toole suggested that there would likely be a group at the CBU level to organize the activities of local roads. When this happens there will be a point of contact for the executive committee. Doyt will attend the Work Force Development meeting presented by FHWA in San Antonio, Texas. MSP Funding will be provided not to exceed $500.

  • Partnership Contacts:
    • AASHTO - Doyt Bolling
    • NACE - Duane and Bruce
    • APWA - Rick and Lisa
    • Salt Institute - Mike Blankenship
  • Delivery Systems:
    This is for delivery systems of the products that the CBUs are developing. Doyt will start this process by getting some initial thoughts together for the board to critique.
  • TRB Agenda:
    • Roll Call and Introductions 15 minutes
    • Secretary Treasurer Report 15 minutes
    • Joe Toole 30 minutes
    • Rural ITS 15 minutes
    • Forest service products 15 minutes
    • Communication Plan 30 minutes
    • Break 30 minutes
    • Clearing House Report 15 minutes
    • NACE Report 15 minutes
    • Advocacy Report 15 minutes
    • AASHTO 15 minutes
    • Salt Institute Report 15 minutes
    • 2002 Annual Meeting 15 minutes
    • Other requests 30 minutes
      Dave will send this agenda to the T2 all list.
  • Ray Griffith Award: The responsibility of shepherding of the recipient will be a responsibility of the past chair. The board will discuss covering all of the expenses to attend the meeting. Dave will send out a request for candidates to consider.
  • Next Annual Report: The board wants to have a second annual report to be similar to the one produced in 2001. Dave will follow up on funding and will discuss with FHWA.
  • Web Site: Terry provided a handout for the National LTAP Association web site. The basis of the site is the 2001 annual report. This is a good effort and was well supported by the
    committee.

December 13, 2001

NACE and National LTAP Executive Board Meeting

Those in attendance included: Tony Giancola NACE Executive Director; Bonnie West NACE Administrative Assistant; John Bell Forest Service; Janet Oakley Director of Policy AASHTO; Bill Evans FHWA; Roger Dean FHWA; Kyung Kyu Lim FHWA; Janeane AATSA; Marcy Kennedy Turner Fairbanks; LTAP Representatives -Dave Grouchy - Chair LTAP Region 6, Walt Slocomb LTAP Region 1, Mike Blankenship LTAP Region 3, Rick Smith LTAP Region 4, Terry McNinch LTAP Region 5, Duane Smith LTAP Region 7, Lisa Harris LTAP Region 7, Doyt Bolling LTAP Region 8, Bruce Drewes LTAP Region 10, Lisa Pogue LTAP Clearing House

  • Legislative Positions and TEA-21 Reauthorization - NACE: Tony briefed the meeting via a handout. The highlights are: A summary of TEA 21, Levels of funding, Funding FACT Sheet, TEA 21 bullet items that define the LTAP program, NACE Legislative/Regulatory Priorities (8/24/01), NaCO-TE A21 Reauthorization Proposal DRAFT, ARTBA (American Road & Transportation Builders Association) o This paper doesnt show a funding level but they have stated a position of $20m in other position papers.
  • Legislative Positions and TEA-21 Reauthorization - AASHTO: Janet Oakley presented handout materials and discussed them. She explained AASHTO's approach to reauthorization, what is in process and what their approach will be. She suggested that we communicate directly with the staff at AASHTO and e- mail is an effective way to have a dialogue. She stated that we might be fighting over a diminished program rather than an expanding program. There is an opportunity for input and to make our views known to AASHTO. The board
    of directors will meet in April and will approve the policy on reauthorization. We could do two things:
  1. Ask for the current status of the research proposal (or workforce development and retention effort)
  2. On behalf of LTAP make the LTAP position known to SCOR which is Dwight Bower from Idaho
  3. Have our own state DOT act as an advocate for LTAP. The workforce development and retention is a CEO level interest. LTAP may need to be packaged as training and workforce development and not in the area of research. Then we can share that with AASHTO. Then we need to look for some champions within the state DOTs.

    We should package and market LTAP the same with all of our partners. If we agree to package and market ourselves with the position of workforce development, we should be consistent with all of our partners. There will be a new cast of staff in the next reauthorization. Bud Wright and Mary Peters are key people to keep in touch with. The Congress, Key Committees, and Helpful Internet Resources Tony presented the current committees that came off the web. Personal staff is an effective way to get the message across. Tonys advice is to use your partners to spread the message. If you dont mention
    specific money you are OK.

    NOTE: We need to have a common position on what we would do with more funding. The position could be four to six positions that come from state LTAP centers. John said to make sure to let them know that you are a resource for them to come back to, leave a business card as a minimum.

    Tony had a handout on the NACE Alert Team that is an electronic update program. NOTE: We need to look at developing a smaller version of the annual report similar to what AASHTO has done with the 2001 Action Agenda.
    Key DOT/FHWA Players

    Minutes from PTO Board Meeting Sept. 7, 2004

    Present at meeting: Lisa Harris, Sister Rachael, Jessica Gueits, Val Salvetti, Rosalina Yu, and Eric Greene,

    Opened meeting with board members prayer led by Lisa Harris.

    Our first topic of discussion was Student Nutrition. Our guest speaker - Mrs. Young from Cooks Catering addressed our school meal program and student nutrition. Cooks abides and exceeds state guidelines and recommends we review our meal order form. Her company has a business practice of keeping the most popular menu items while offering new nutritionally focused options.

    Nutritional concerns from parents and faculty stem from an array of issues including wasted food and unhealthy menu options. For example: Menu options such as corn dog coupled with a pretzel amounts to a double carbohydrate dish that lacks other essential food groups. Quality control in relation to student health is an issue as well as developing good eating habits. Several studies link insufficient nutrition to poor concentration, obesity, diabetes, high cholesterol and other health issues.

    Action items regarding school nutrition:

    1. Snack portion was of biggest concern and will be regulated moving forward. Faculty has imposed the new restriction of no soda or candy sold from the school.

    2. We will review new menus after one month test. Focus from Cooks Catering will now be to balance menu and review available snacks. The goal is to offer less starch and greasy food such as hash browns. Question raised -- Do we want to go into a card system for our snack service? We are also reviewing successful practices from other schools.

    3. Nutrition and exercise should become a greater part of our education through take home information. We may also include a guest nutrition speaker at future PTO meetings.

    Lisa Harris conducted a review of Parent Teacher Board Constitution, By-Laws and Code of Ethics.
    Key points:

    1. Outline of each officers duties
    2. All boards are advisory. Pastor has final say
    3. We are looking forward to receiving any input/issues or topics from parents.

    As a group we discussed school board goals for 2004. Sister Rachael led our discussion regarding back to school topics of conduct. We need to act in a family spirit and look out for each other We stress to our students A call to greatness. What it means to be spiritual and have genuine values. Its the Salesian philosophy. As a community we have the proper channels to address hot issues. Jessica Gueits stated her goal of community attitude as one of pride, positive image, and school spirit. Lisa Harris stressed how important it is that we appreciate and publicize our accomplishments. Jessica commented that we are fortunate to have a devoted community As a school community we need to reach out to the teachers and ask, What can we do to help you do you job.

    In closing:

    An ongoing concern for our school is declining enrollment. There is a national decline in catholic education. At Sts P&P, we are ten students low in attendance / tuition this year. We need to keep in mind the balance of wants to what we can afford. As an institution we need to consider how to effectively build on our image and community. We need to offer scholarship opportunities for future growth and diversity.

    Summary of immediate goals for 2004 -2005

    • Marketing - Grant and fund raising [broaden the base of funding] who can help us [some parents may do this for a living]
    • Science lab done [whats next on the wish list]
    • Improve website [this is a great tool to distribute information and foster public image]
    • Offer Sunday Church Services that are youth friendly for students and student families
    • Dinner [maybe] and daycare on night of the PTO meetings to improve experience and build community [use 8th graders with adult supervision for child care]

    Action items for Parent Committees:

    1. Get a group/committee together with emphasis on fund raising and other functions.
      Key appointments include:
      • Publicity/Fund Raising Committee
      • Hospitality Committee
      • Room Parents Committee
      • Social Events Committee

    2. Parent Assistance
      • Lunch hour
      • Library

Lisa Harris receives outstanding alumna award

June 4, 2004

  
Tucson, AZ - Lisa Harris, Ph.D., founder and President of Harris Environmental Group, was recently awarded an Outstanding Alumna award from the University of Arizona. Harris is an Adjunct Research Scientist in the School of Natural Resources and continues to contribute to the program through teaching and serving as a professional role model. She is involved with monitoring, inventories, habitat restoration, biological and cultural resource studies, conservation planning, ESA consultation, and environmental education. She is an active member of the conservation community and received the Arizona Chapter of the Wildlife Societies Conservation Award in 2001. Harris received her Ph.D. in Wildlife and Fisheries Sciences in 1992.

Business News Monday, February 3, 2003
Mail this page
People with disabilities embrace entrepreneurship
By Marcus Green
magreen@courier-journal.com
The Courier-Journal


Forced to leave one job because of carpal tunnel syndrome, Lisa Harris opened Flight of Fantasy Florist & Nursery. In addition to her Shelbyville Road flower shop, she said she will open two more greenhouses this spring and hopes to start a nursery in Henry County.
PHOTOS BY MICHAEL HAYMAN

The carpal tunnel syndrome bore into Lisa Harris' fingers, shot like lightning up her arms and wracked her elbows.

It became too painful to type and dial phone numbers at her job as a Sprint salesperson. And because she has lupus, surgery was not an option.

So these days she is settling into her first year as owner of Flight of Fantasy Florist & Nursery -- a dream she pursued after leaving Sprint.

But every day Harris is reminded of her carpal tunnel syndrome. She can't push a lawn mower, hammer, write longhand, tie ribbons on balloons, or dig soil. ''It's everyday things that people don't think about,'' she said.

Harris' story is not unique. Because of its flexibility and independence, self-employment is a viable -- and common -- option for those with disabilities.

''People with disabilities are self-employed at higher rates than people without disabilities,'' said University of Montana researcher Nancy Arnold, who has tracked trends among entrepreneurs with disabilities.

According to 1990 census statistics, the most recent available, 12 percent of working-age people with disabilities are self-employed, compared with 8 percent among the overall work force, she said.

Meanwhile, Congress is not funding the U.S. Small Business Administration's handicapped-assistance loan program. The Greater Louisville Small Business Development Center refers inquiries to the Kentucky Department of Vocational Rehabilitation.
"So it's not like if you're disabled, you can go out there and say, 'OK, I want a business loan.'"

-- Lisa Harris, florist owner

''We've had a real focus on selfemployment in the past years,'' said department program administrator Robin Fowler. Of the 4,557 disabled people who found employment through the department in the 2001-2002 fiscal year, 56 were self-employed. The percentage of those job seekers who started their own businesses has hovered between 1 percent and 2 percent the past five years.

The department helped Harris get Flight of Fantasy off the ground.

Once she had polished her business plan, she began seeking fi-nancing. She ultimately took out a home-equity line of credit and bought a $33,000 certificate of de-posit to use as collateral on a small-business loan from Republic Bank.

Her classic bootstrapping paid off.

She contacted the Department of Vocational Rehabilitation's Louisville office, which gave her money for office equipment and several ladders for her greenhouses.

Harris estimates she received about $7,000 in equipment, including computer supplies and a fax machine.

''I had to have monies in place to open the business before they would help me. I had to have the business up and running to a certain degree before they would put any money into it,'' she said. ''So it's not like if you're disabled, you can go out there and say, 'OK, I want a business loan.' ''

Had she not received assistance, Harris is confident that she would have found money for the equipment. But the government assistance ''allows me to spend more money on the floral product and go out and do bridal shows and stuff, and invest that money that way to get my name out there to promote my company.''

Her approach seems to be working. In addition to her East End flower shop, she said she will open two more greenhouses this spring and hopes to start a nursery in Henry County, Ky.

Few disabled entrepreneurs seek outside financing in starting their ventures. Arnold, the University of Montana researcher, surveyed 316 disabled business owners in 1999. She found that more than half financed their start-up costs with their savings. A smaller number relied on credit cards and loans from family members. Less than 16 percent used a bank loan or grants from a vocational rehabilitation agency.

The study by the Research and Training Center on Rural Rehabilitation Services reported no correlation between the type of business owned and the entrepreneur's disability. In addition, more than half of those surveyed said they had previously owned their own business.

Overall, about 20 percent of those surveyed said they had closed their most recent business. The most common reason? Not enough capital. Twenty-five percent of those said they closed because of their disability.

John Johnson, who is quadriplegic, falls into that category. He built a computer consulting company, Midwest CAD Systems. Retail operations began in Louisville in 1984.

Over the years, he said, clients recognized him for his ability rather than for his disability. ''I was legitimized more as far as (people saying), 'He's disabled, but he's the owner and he's got 10 employees.' ''
"People with disabilities are self-employed at higher rates than people without disabilities."

-- University of Montana researcher Nancy Arnold; Self-employment can become harbor for the disabled in working world

But there were other obstacles an able-bodied entrepreneur would not have to think twice about. He had to hire someone to make sales calls, for example.

''Part of my disability is what was the demise of my company in the long run,'' he said. ''When we started having rough times, I couldn't go out and get into places and work on their computers. I had to hire, basically, a person-and-a-half to do a job that, if I wasn't in a chair, I could do myself.''

He said his disability kept him from absorbing other roles within the company, such as bookkeeping.

''I do it at a slower rate. Being a quadriplegic I can't type as fast. . . . I can't sort papers. I can't put things away. I can't file things as fast as someone else can do it.''

Working on a tight payroll, Johnson said, he couldn't afford to hire additional employees. By the time the company went out of business in 2000, he was down to four employees, including himself.

Johnson, who today works as a consultant for one of his former employees, said he is still struggling to pay off a handicapped-accessibility loan he received from the Small Business Administration.

The bulk of the loan was to be used for equipment purchases, he said.

''I needed salespeople. I needed technicians. You know, I didn't need a bunch of equipment that basically went out of date in four or five months.''

Johnson declined to say how much money he owes, but concedes ''it's more money than I have.''

''I just can't go out and get a job someplace.''

Scholarship Established in Memory of Nathan Harris Family

Gardner Altman, Jr., a Dunn native and longtime friend of the Oscar Harris family, has made a generous contribution to Campbell University with the express purpose of endowing a scholarship to unceasingly remember the Nathan and Lisa Harris family, which was tragically killed in an airplane crash, Saturday, March 1, 2003.

In making the contribution, Altman said, My family has literally grown up with the Oscar Harris family. The young Nathan Harris family, so tragically wiped out in an instance in time, was an inspiration to everyone who knew them. We can do no less than establish a scholarship which will forever keep their memory and inspiration alive amongst us.

The scholarship is to be named The Nathan and Lisa Harris Family Memorial Social Work and Education Endowed Scholarship and will be awarded annually to worthy students who are pursuing careers in social work or education at Campbell University. Priority for awarding the scholarship will go first to a graduate of a high school in Bladen County, second to a resident of Bladen County, or third to a North Carolina resident. Family and friends of the Harris family wishing to do so may make a contribution to the scholarship by sending a check to:

Campbell University
Advancement Office
P. O Box 116
Buies Creek, NC 27506.

The check should be marked for the Harris Memorial Scholarship.

Harris to lead Wishard Health Services

Lisa Harris, MD, is the new medical director and chief executive officer of Wishard Health Services. Her nomination was approved Dec. 22 by the Board of Trustees of Health and Hospital Corporation of Marion County and D. Craig Brater, MD, IUSM dean.

“I am eager to begin this new role and very optimistic about Wishard’s future,“ said Dr. Harris, who also was named an associate dean of Wishard Affairs at the School of Medicine. “While I will be working closely with Wishard’s board and administrative leadership to stabilize our financial future, I also look forward to working with the physicians and staff to further enhance the care we provide to the Indianapolis community.”

For the past four years, Dr. Harris has served as chief of medicine at Wishard. She also is the executive vice president and chief medical officer for IU Medical Group – Primary Care.

“Lisa Harris has a wealth of experience as a clinician and manager,” said Dr. Brater. “She is a recognized expert in meeting patients' needs. Her breadth of experience coupled with having practiced medicine at Wishard her entire career means she is uniquely equipped to lead Wishard during this important time. She will be a wonderful bridge between the School of Medicine and Health and Hospital Corporation as we work in partnership to meet the needs of the underserved of Marion County.”

A 1983 graduate of the IU School of Medicine, Dr. Harris completed an internship, residency and fellowship in internal medicine, as well as a fellowship in nephrology. She served as chief medicine resident at Wishard from 1988 to 1989 and was an attending physician there when she received her first academic appointment in the School’s Department of Medicine.

Since that time, Dr. Harris has advanced many programs for preventive and therapeutic care and also has been an effective health science researcher with her interests focusing on using patients’ reports and evaluations of care to drive health care quality improvement.

Dr. Harris has participated in leadership development courses for health care executives at the Harvard School of Public Health and the National Association of Public Hospitals. In 2003, she was named an Outstanding Female Faculty Leader by the Office for Women of Indiana University-Purdue University, Indianapolis. She is a diplomat of the American Board of Internal Medicine.

Dr. Harris succeeds Robert B. Jones, MD, PhD, who was appointed executive associate dean for strategic planning, analysis and operations in the IU School of Medicine. Jones served as CEO and medical director of Wishard for nearly four years.

BACK TO TOP

Yoder named Klingler Professor of Pediatrics

Mervin Yoder Jr., MD, has been named the Richard and Pauline Klingler Professor of Pediatrics.

Dr. Yoder is a professor of pediatrics and of biochemistry and molecular biology. A 1980 graduate of IUSM, he has served on the faculty since 1985.

The Richard and Pauline Klingler Professorship was established by the Riley Children’s Foundation in 2001. The Klinglers grandson, Zachary, died from cancer at Riley Hospital. The family has been supporters of IUSM and Riley Hospital for several years and have had a particular interest in clinical and research cancer programs.

The Klingler Professorship is designated for a pediatrician who is in a major leadership role in patient care, teaching and/or research at Riley Hospital.

BACK TO TOP

Brain surgeon, local congresswoman among Diversity Week speakers

Several speakers and topics will help recognize Diversity Week and honor the legacy of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

Pediatric neurosurgeon Benjamin Carson Sr., known for his expertise in separating conjoined twins and conducting brain surgery to control seizures, will deliver the keynote address at the 34th annual IUPUI dinner honoring Dr. King.

Carson, who first gained international recognition as the principal surgeon in the 22-hour separation of conjoined twins from Germany in 1987, will speak at the dinner to be at 6 p.m., Monday, Jan. 19, at the Indiana Roof Ballroom.

The theme for the dinner is “Striving for Excellence and Continuing the Dream.” Tickets for the King Dinner are $20 each for IUPUI undergraduate students, $35 for IUPUI faculty and staff, and $35 for community guests. Tickets are available through Campus and Community Life at 274-3931, or on the Web site at www.life.iupui.edu/CCL/diversity/MLK.asp.

The afternoon of Jan. 19, Dr. Carson will speak on the IUPUI campus from 2:30 p.m. to 3:30 p.m. His presentation “Gifted Hands – The Ben Carson Story” will be at the University Place Conference Center auditorium.

IUSM Diversity Week Events

The 2004 dinner is a collaborative event sponsored by the IU School of Medicine, the IUPUI Black Student Union, the IUPUI MLK Dinner Committee and the Student National Medical Association.

Other speakers, scheduled by the IUSM Diversity Council, will present from noon to 1 p.m. in Emerson Hall auditorium. Lunch will be served. are:

  • Monday, Jan. 12 – William Lawson, MD, PhD, professor and chair, Department of Psychiatry, Howard University, “Diagnosing and Treating Bipolar Disorder in African-Americans”
  • Tuesday, Jan. 13 – Clive Callendar, MD, professor and chair, Department of Surgery and director of transplant surgery at Howard University, “From Birth to the Minority Organ Tissue Transplant Education Program – The Clive Callendar Story”
  • Wednesday, Jan. 14 – Elena Rios, MD, president, Hispanic Medical Association, “Federal Health Policy 2003 – A National Minority Health Care Advocate’s Perspective”
  • Thursday, Jan. 15 – Rep. Julia Carson, D-Ind., “Women’s Health Issues – An Individual and Legislator’s Perspective”

BACK TO TOP

Continuing Medical Education gets accreditation kudos

IUSM’s Continuing Medical Education program has received a four-year accreditation from the Accreditation Council for Continuing Medical Education (ACCME). The School’s program earned an exemplary overall program evaluation and has been invited to participate in ACCME’s Best Practices program.

The ACCME is a consortium of professional organizations that set the standards for continuing medical education.

The Continuing Medical Education program offers high quality education programs to faculty, alumni and practicing physicians in Indiana and throughout the nation through recurring events such as grand rounds, courses in Indiana and nationally, visiting professor programs and other materials such as books, videos, CD-ROMs and Web-based programs.

BACK TO TOP

Mini Medical School features surgical updates

Are you ready to scrub for the latest topics and issues in surgery? That is the direction surgeons at IUSM will take participants at the winter series of IU Mini Medical School, Feb. 10 through March 16. Each of the two-hour weekly sessions meets at 7 p.m. Tuesdays in the lower-level auditorium at the Riley Outpatient Center.

Topics and speakers include:

Feb. 10 The History and Future of Surgery
Keith Lillemoe, MD, and Jay Grosfeld, MD
Feb. 17 The Skinny on Bariatric Surgery
Clark Simons, MD
Feb. 24 Robots and Computers Lend A Helping Hand
David Canal, MD, and Don Selzer, MD
March 2-9 The Organ Trail: New Pathways In Transplantation
A. Joseph Tector, MD
(other guest speakers may present at these sessions)
March 16 You’re So Vein: Vascular Surgery
Stephen Lalka, MD, and Matthew Johnson, MD

One of the main goals of the twice-annual IU Mini Medical School is to introduce and explain to the public - in everyday language - the latest developments and topical issues in health care and research.

Cost to attend the six-week series is $40 per person and advanced registration is required. For information or to register, call 317-278-7600. When registering, refer to Course No. 033N01A200.

IU Mini Medical School is sponsored by the IU Medical Group and Indianapolis radio station WIBC, and is offered by the IU School of Medicine Faculty Community Relations through the IUPUI Division of Continuing Studies.

Combined Seminar Series for January

The January Combined Seminar Series, held from 4 p.m. to 5 p.m. Wednesdays in the IU Cancer Research Institute auditorium, will feature:

Jan. 14 – David Ranshoff, MD, professor of medicine, clinical professor of epidemiology, director, Clinical Research Curriculum, University of North Carolina -- Chapel Hill

Medical Humanities Seminar – Jan. 21

Sandra Petronio, PhD, IUPUI Department of Communications and the IU Center for Bioethics, will speak from noon to 1 p.m. Wednesday, Jan. 21, at the Seminars in Medical Ethics and Humanities. Her presentation, “Riddles of Privacy in Today’s World,” will be in the Medical Library, room 301-302.

The previously scheduled talk for January, Carol Gardner’s “Multiple Metaphors: Patterns of Stigma Self-presentation,” has been postponed.

The Seminars are open to the public but space is limited. Lunch is provided with a reservation, which can be made by calling 274-4740 or by emailing Judi Campbell at jizukac@iupui.edu.

BACK TO TOP

Technology discount deadline Jan. 14

Individuals enrolled in the IUSM PDA initiative are eligible for technology discounts through Wednesday, Jan. 14, on the Tungsten C (Listed price is $499, IUSM discounted price is $350, plus an extended warranty). There also are discounts available on software through Skyscape and for ePocrates. Training opportunities will be available for PDA use, recommended software/resources listings and more opportunities to come in the future. To access the area of the Web to receive the discount for the Tungsten C, users must be enrolled in the Angel IUSM PDA course. Once enrolled, users can log on to Angel with their user identification and password, go to the content area, choose Discounts Directory and go to the IUSM/CDWG website.

The PDA Initiative

There is no doubt that handheld technology is pervasive. Exposing medical students to handhelds and incorporating the technology and resources into the medical education experience is essential. As medical students move from the four-year program into residencies, specialty programs and into practice, they will be expected to be PDA-aware; and in some cases, able to use handheld technology within clinical/hospital/private practice infrastructures from the moment they walk in the door.

The IUSM Educational Technology, Medical Library and Medical Student Affairs Computer Support groups formed a handheld technology team with a goal to provide opportunities for IUSM students to gain handheld technology experience and to assist teaching faculty incorporate handheld technology, resources and projects into the medical education curriculum. The team has developed the IUSM PDA Program.

The program is based on a single, recommended handheld platform - Palm Tungsten C - to provide comprehensive support and services including:

  • Hardware and software discounts for IUSM students, faculty and staff
  • Medical Library Reference Librarians’ list of evaluated and recommended medical software/resources
  • Training opportunities for basic PDA use, PDA medical software
  • PDA custom content, application and project development consultation
  • Faculty consultation to incorporate handheld technology in teaching environments
  • Technical troubleshooting assistance
  • IUSM PDA/Handheld Technology resources

An Angel course has been created – the IUSM PDA Community – as a one-stop-shop for information, recommended software, FAQs, technical support, and vendor discounts.

Email your name and IU/IUPUI Network ID to Amy Hatfield (ajhatfie@iupui.edu) or Mary Beth Nance (mnance@iupui.edu) to enroll in the course and take advantage of the developing resources/vendor discounts.

For more information see http://et.medicine.iu.edu/PDA/AnnouncementPDA.pdf.

BACK TO TOP

PDA Brown Bag Lunch-n-Learn Series begins Jan. 30

The first in a monthly series of PDA information and training Brown Bag Lunch-n-Learn sessions will be from noon until 1:30 p.m., Friday, Jan. 30, in the Van Nuys Medical Science Building B26.

Grant Olsen, MS3, will discuss the use of handheld devices in medical school, demonstrate the HanDBase application and give an overview on HotSyncing.

He will use the Tungsten C, the IUSM PDA recommended model, and the model that is currently available for purchase at a 30 percent discount with extended warranty until Wednesday, Jan. 14.

There will be time for questions at the end of the session.

BACK TO TOP

Taylor Awards for Excellence in Diversity nominations sought

Nominations and applications are being accepted for the third annual IUPUI Dr. Joseph T. Taylor Excellence in Diversity Awards. Dr. Taylor was the first dean of the IU School of Liberal Arts at IUPUI.

The awards will be conferred by Chancellor Charles Bantz during the 16th Annual Joseph T. Taylor Symposium on Feb. 19. Awards will be selected from nominations or applications submitted by faculty, staff or students in recognition of exemplary IUPUI academic and support programs, events, policies and activities that have led to the following:

  • Increased recruitment and/or retention of African American and Hispanic faculty, students and staff
  • Enhanced campus climate for diversity through social, cultural, or developmental programs or events
  • Engagement of the IUPUI community in issues related to race, class or gender through innovative curriculum, research, programs or events.

The nomination/application form must be submitted no later than Tuesday, Jan. 20. Forms can be found at www.iupui.edu/joseph_t_taylor/.

Completed forms should be sent to:

Taylor Diversity Awards
c/o Lillian Charleston
IUPUI Affirmative Action Office
355 N. Lansing St., AO127
Indianapolis, IN 46202
317 274-2306, fax: 317 274-3963
affaindy@iupui.edu

BACK TO TOP

Honors

Susan Ballinger, MD, associate professor of pediatric rheumatology, has been named by the National Board of Medical Examiners to the the Step 2 Clinical Skills Physical Exam Advisory Committee in the development of U.S. Licensing Examination. Test committee members develop and review test items that compose the USMLE.

Herbert Cushing, MD, is the medical school liaison representative to the National Board of Medical Examiners. As a representative, Dr. Cushing has oversight responsibility for IUSM’s connection to the NBME secure website and the individuals designated to access it.

Debomoy Lahiri, PhD, professor of medical neurobiology and of medical and molecular genetics, has been awarded the Distinguished Scientist Award from the Association of Scientists of Indian Origin in America – Neuroscience Division during the 33rd annual meeting of the Society for Neuroscience meeting in New Orleans. The Distinguished Scientist Award is the highest award presented by ASIOA in recognition of scientific achievement in neuroscience.

BACK TO TOP

This week on Sound Medicine

Tune in at noon, Saturday, Jan. 17, to Sound Medicine, the weekly radio program co-produced by IUSM and WFYI Public Radio (90.1 FM) in Indianapolis. The program is hosted by Barb Lewis. This week’s co-host is Steve Bogdewic, PhD.

Guests include Robert Patterson, a third-year medical student and coordinator of IUSM’s Diversity Week activities. He will discuss his goal of encouraging more minorities to enter medical school and the health professions. Diversity Week speaker Benjamin Carson, MD, Johns Hopkins neurosurgeon, who is renowned for separating numerous conjoined twins. He also is an advocate for recruiting minorities into health care. Dr. Carson also is the IUPUI Martin Luther King Day guest speaker.

Also appearing is Martin Farlow, MD, professor of neurology, who will discuss the latest Mad Cow scare and prion diseases.

Archived editions of Sound Medicine, as well as other helpful health information, can be found at soundmedicine.iu.edu.

Online IUSM calendars

A comprehensive listing on IUSM seminars, lectures and Grand Rounds can be accessed at www.medlib.iupui.edu/calendar. To place items on the Scientific Calendar, please forward them to Iona Sewell at imsewell@iupui.edu.

A Special Events Calendar for presentations, symposiums, conferences and other activities at IUSM can be found on the School's Web page at www.medicine.iu.edu. The calendar also can be accessed directly at webdb.iu.edu/iusm/scripts/calendar/instr.cfm.

BACK TO TOP

Submissions to Scope

Scope wants your news items.

The deadline for submission is 8:30 a.m. on Fridays. Scope is published electronically and sent to faculty, staff, students, and residents.

There are four easy ways to submit story ideas or information to Scope:

  • fax the information to 278-8722
  • e-mail the information to mhardin@iupui.edu
  • mail the information to Mary Hardin, Z-7, Ste. 306, IUPUI
  • paste your plain text message into Scope Web form on the IUSM faculty & staff page: http://medicine.iu.edu/faculty

Contributions submitted by e-mail should be forwarded in 12 point, plain text format.
To keep the electronic version of Scope as streamlined as possible, only seminars and lectures of general or multidisciplinary interest will be included.

Minutes: Urban Wildlife Working Group Meeting (unapproved)
Held in conjunction with The Wildlife Society Annual Meeting
September 13,2000, Room 212 Renaissance Convention Center, 3:30 pm – 5:30 pm
Meeting called to order at 3:35 pm by chair, Lowell Adams.

35 people in attendance (Attachment 1). Handouts attached. The chair noted that due notice of the meeting was given by TWS in its preliminary program and that an announcement was placed on the group’s web page. Adams also noted that a quorum was present because more than 12 active members were in attendance. Brief self introductions of attendees were made.

Chair report (Lowell Adams)

Activities report (1999) handed out (copy available on web page)

Lowell expresses his thanks to volunteers of the standing Symposia committees. The Urban Working Group is sponsoring 2 symposia at this meeting. The Working Group expresses thanks to John Hadidian and Kate Sternberg for co-coordinating and to Lisa Harris and John Hadidian for moderating. The session yesterday was well attended (count ranged from 97 to 120 people) and very well done.

Web page – can be accessed through The Wildlife Society home page (www.wildlife.org). Thanks to Mark Wallace for putting up and maintaining that site.

Plant list – At the last meeting the working group decided that it was important to put together a list of native plants appropriate for landscape use. Mark Johns (Southeast) and Carolyn Engle-Wilson (desert Southwest) agreed to assemble lists. At the present meeting, Kelly Bender (Texas) and Howard Ferguson (Pacific Northwest) also agreed to help. Volunteers are needed to complete this project.

Newsletter – See "Unfinished Business"

Elections – See Nominations and Elections committee report below

Lowell called for a motion to accept the Chair Report. Laurie Brown made the motion and Mark Wallace provided a second. The motion carried by acclamation. The Chair’s full report is attached as a part of these minutes (Attachment 2).

Treasurers Report (Bob Bruleigh, given by proxy by Lowell Adams)

Balance – $1805.56

Motion proposed to accept the Treasurer’s Report. Allen made the motion and a second was provided by Laurie Brown. The motion carried by acclamation. The Treasurer’s full report is attached as a part of these minutes (Attachment 3).

Nomination and Elections committee (Larry VanDruff)

State of upcoming elections – Larry reminds of the available offices (President elect, Secretary/Treasurer, 3 Board positions), and that at least 2 candidates must run in each election. Candidates must be paid members of the Urban Working Group and must be able to attend most of the meetings. Terms for the board will be staggered 2-year terms.

Nominations – Nominations will be taken for the next week. Subsequently, Larry will issue a preliminary slate to members. Members can add nominations to the preliminary slate with signatures from 6 members. One or two months after the preliminary slate is delivered, a final slate will be issued.

Larry presented the committee report, noting that the slate of candidates needed to be finalized. Howard Ferguson moved acceptance of the report and Mark Wallace seconded the motion. The report was then opened to the group for discussion. Kate Stenberg was nominated by Larry VanDruff to run for Chair-Elect (she needs to be contacted for agreement). Mark Wallace nominated Kelly Bender to run for Secretary-Treasurer (she agreed to do so). Clint Boal was nominated by Mark Wallace to run for Board member (he needs to be contacted for agreement). Howard Ferguson and Laurie Brown nominated themselves to run for the Board. There being no further discussion the report, as amended, was adopted.

Membership (Tommy Parker, not present) No report

Annual meeting technical sessions (Kate Sternberg, not present)

The symposia at this meeting will stand as this report. The minutes reflect the exceptionally capable manner in which the session was conducted. Thanks to all who were involved.

A new chair needs to be named.

Communications – No report

Special committee reports

College and University – (Clark Adams, not present) His presentation at the symposium yesterday will stand as his report.

Model State Agency Nongame Program (John Herron, not present, Lowell summarizes previous conversations) If CARA passes, this will become extremely important. Urban programs will certainly need to be included in State wildlife programs. The model state agency nongame program report is currently in draft form.

Publications – No report. Lowell adds that this should come up in new business.

International affairs – (Lowell Adams) Past meeting attendees showed interest in holding the Urban Wildlife conference outside the US. International wildlife professionals interested included Peter Brown, George Barker, and David Goode of England. Four international Working Group members contacted by Lowell showed interest in assisting as well. There is a possibility that a meeting could be held in conjunction with the International Wildlife Congress (TWS) now apparently favored (noted informally) to be held in New Zealand. There will also be a Wildlife Damage conference in Israel soon. A motion to accept this report was made by Mark Wallace and Lisa Harris provided a second. Discussion followed, primarily focusing on the merits of holding international conferences, and whether the conferences might alternate on a regular schedule between national and international platforms. The motion carried by acclamation. The Chair’s full report is attached as a part of these minutes (Attachment 4).

Urban Wildlife Symposia (Lisa Harris (reporting) and Bill Shaw) Past meetings indicated that Larry, Lisa, and Bill continue to work on proceedings. Lisa reports that they’d like to help better papers to have an issue in a peer reviewed journal. There hasn’t yet been interest expressed in a location for the next meeting. Larry reminds that criteria for selecting locations are available through TWS. We’ll use these guidelines when we issue an RFP (request for proposals). Lisa explains the commitment necessary to put on the conference: For the last conference, $30,000 was obtained through a USFWS grant, an additional $10 to $15,000 was obtained through Lisa’s company. The University provided administrative support and student volunteers. Planning took about 2 years. Approximately 300 people attended the meeting, and over 100 presentations were given. Urban Forestry was suggested as a possible collaborator, though it was noted that in previous years they were not interested. John Hadidian recommended issuing a RFP. Bill and Lisa can begin modifying guidelines to fit our scope. A motion to accept the report was made by Mark Wallace, Laurie Brown provided a second. The motion carried by acclamation.

Unfinished business: Newsletter – (Charlie Nilon, not present) Laurie Brown offered to help produce the newsletter. It is proposed that the newsletter be issues regularly, perhaps 2 issues per year. Mark Wallace offers to post it on the website. John Hadidian suggests that it needs to go out ASAP, and assumes responsibility of producing the first issue. The main business of the first issue will be nominations. The format will be suggested by the committee and can be decided by the board or the membership

New Business

Annual Meeting Technical Session – October 30th is the due date for proposals to TWS for a symposium or workshop. Tom Franklin reports that workshops are more "hand-on" discussions and are in high demand. Lisa Harris proposes the topic "Regional planning as a management tool for wildlife conservation." After discussion and suggestions for examples, it was agreed that this is a topic worth pursuing. John Hadidian suggested support of Lisa’s proposal, Larry provided a second. The proposal was accepted by acclamation. Lisa will draft the proposal to TWS. Laurie Brown volunteered to assist.

Publications: Discussion of our role in publications – Take this session’s materials and produce for the Bulletin. Mark volunteers to help. If items for publication come from a working group, Tom suggests acceptance might be easier. Larry would like to see more activity on the listserve. Mark Wallace calls for material for the website. Suggestions include links in current literature, ProCite information, links to urban project websites, abstracts from presentations at this meeting, and PowerPoint presentations. To contact Mark: mwallace@ttacs.ttu.edu. The website is www.rw.ttu.edu/urbwlf. It can also be accessed through TWS homepage (www.wildlife.org). Subscribe to the listserve by sending an e-mail to listserv@uriacc.uri.edu with the word "subscribe" in the body. Turn off automatic signatures and leave the subject line blank.

International Symposium – John Hadidian reported strong interest from Peter Shirley (England). David Goode is now with the mayor’s office and could provide a strong, supportive resource. Lowell (and others) agree that we should pursue national and international meetings. Further discussion followed, including naming the conference, alternating national and international conferences, the role of the working group in those conferences, partnering with other international conferences, having TWS as an annual forum (particularly for state agency personnel), the inclusion of local developers and policy makers at the meetings, and submission of an RFP. Decision was made to have informal discussions with the London contacts and inform them that official contact will be made through committee (Lisa) Lowell suggested that discussion be continued by the board.

Announcement: John Hadidian wishes to note the passing last year of John Gottschalk. John was the Director of the USFWS. Among other notable contributions to the field of wildlife management and conservation, he provided invaluable support to the first Urban Wildlife Conference. His support and guidance will be missed.

Adjournment: Lowell notes that the Executive Board will meet immediately following this meeting. All are welcomed to attend. A motion to adjourn was made by Larry VanDruff and was seconded by Laurie Brown. The motion carried by acclamation.

Minutes respectfully submitted September 14, 2000 by Kelly Bender.

What's Happening / Events / Around the Market

Activities and Events Around the Market

Current and upcoming events sponsored by Market businesses and agencies include:

 

Art Stall Gallery

Jan WrunExhibit

October 29 - November 26, 2004

November features an exhibit of gallery artist Jan Wrun. Her popular watercolors feature beautiful soft washes and vibrant colors depicting both landscapes and florals. Open 10 am - 6 pm Monday through Saturday. Located in the Economy Arcade.

Lisa Harris Gallery

Kim Osgood, monotypes

November 4 - 27, 2004

Lisa Harris Gallery presents new monotypes by Kim Osgood in an exhibition opening Thursday, November 4 from 6:00 - 8:00 pm. The artists's one-of-a-kind prints, created using a viscocity printing technique, assemble everyday objects, fruits, birds, and architectural elements in abstract compositions which evoke the fleeting nature of experience. Monday - Saturday 10:30 am - 5:30 pm; Sunday 11 am - 4 pm. Lisa Harris Gallery is at 1922 Pike Place (on the second floor).

Cintli

Dia de los Muertos Celebration

November 2004

Come and celebrate the colorful folklore of the long-lasting Mexican tradition of the Day of the Death. We will offer discounts, Mexican treats, surprises and more. Third floor DownUnder.

Lisa Harris Gallery

Pastels and Paintings by Joel Brock

December 2 -30, 2004

This December, Lisa Harris Gallery features recent pastels and paintings by Joel Brock. The artist will be present at the First Thursday opening on December 2 from 6:00 to 8:00 p.m. Known for his understanding of light and contour, Brock pushes the traditional boundaries of the pastel genre by adding other medi to the mix and deconstructing his still ife and architectural subjects. Monday - Saturday 10:30 am - 5:30 pm; Sunday 11 am - 4 pm. Lisa Harris Gallery is at 1922 Pike Place (on the second floor).

Cintli

Posadas

December 2004

Come and celebrate the eight day Mexican Christmas celebration from December 16 - 24. Cintli will offer traditional Mexican Christmas treats and lots of discounted items to make your holiday shopping more easy and affordable. Third floor DownUnder.

Art Stall Gallery

Sally Rawling Exhibit

December 2004

December features an exhibit of Sally Rawling's beautiful, peaceful watercolor landscapes, painted with elegant simplicity. Open 10 am - 6 pm Monday through Saturday. Located in the Economy Arcade.

  • Christmas for Kids wonderful update! -- Tracy Kemble, 11:46:48 11/21/04 Sun [1]
    Many Greetings to all of you. I am sitting here feeling very blessed right now. Two weeks ago, I received an email informing us that we would not have 60 children, but instead 140 children in the home in Bulgaria. Well, Mrs. Globe, our SMILE Dentists and friends, family and supporters of WIN stepped up and guess what?! One month out, we are almost at our goal. I would like to show you what we have secured right now for the babies / children. We are very excited as each need is close to being met for our Mrs. Globe / Christmas for Kids in Bulgaria, even after we doubled our number of children!

    As of today we have:
    - 140 pairs of sweat and wind pants for all the kids.
    - 72 sets of playwear for all 60 babies, 0 12 months old.
    - 60 fleece bear blanket for all 60 babies, 0 12 months old.
    - 22 Teddy Bear Playwear set for all 22 baby girls, 1 2 years old
    - 22 Jacket and Pant set for all 22 baby boys, 1 2 years old.
    - 140 white Teddy Bear for all 140 kids.
    - 3 coats for the younger children
    - Small toys for the younger children
    - 99 Tooth brush kits for all the kids.
    - 150 pair of socks (thanks Theresa Dame!)

    We are almost to our goal! All we need now is:
    - Warm outfits for the 11 boys, 2 3 and 11 girls, 2 3 (some of these have been provided for. If you are intersted in shopping for these, let us know.)
    - 9 warm outfits for the 9 children, 3 9.
    - Underware for all of the non-daiper children
    - Pampers (WIN of Ukraine and WIN of Azerbaijan are working on this)
    - Milk / Nan (Which we will purchase there)
    - Tents for the window (I am finding out how many windows)
    - And money for a new sink.
    - I am presenting something to the orphanage on national TV, on their number one show, so any ideas for honorary gift, is welcome!

    Our Travel Team to Bulgaria will be:
    - Me (Tracy Kemble)
    - Monica Ulrich, DOM for WIN and Mrs. Globe
    - Liz Eddy, Mrs. US Globe 2003
    - Nancy Stern, WIN BOD
    - Kenny Luper, videographer
    - Pauline Roberson, Contestant Coordinator
    - Inna Maystruck coming in from Ukraine
    - Narmina Bakinez Mrs. Azerbaijan 2005.
    - Possibly Dr. Erich Herber


    Thank you all for helping make this happen incredible event happen. I appreciate you all so much, as does Mrs. Globe (Rumiana Marinova), the home for children who will be warm for Christmas. I love you all and will give you a final update prior to our departure.



    My respect

    TRACY

    Tomorrow Scot and I will be celebrating our 8th anniversary. That is not the point of my note. the point is to share my gift idea with you. Right now if you walk in to those Teen Jewelry stores (in my part of the country I would suggest Clarie's) you see these bags and notebooks and Tshirts with all types of Mrs. names on them like Mrs. Pitt, Mrs Bloom and Mrs Kutcher. As proud as Scot is to be Mr. Washington, at times He does occasionally lose his name to the title. I am going to have a Tshirt made for myself for his gift that says Mrs. Hunsperger on it. I much more proud to be his husband and I thought It would be a fun way to honor him for his support and losing his name for a week during pageant season.

    I share my idea as I thought with the holidays around the corner someone might get some inspiration for a fun gift. The only rule is you must share your ideas back to me.

    I just wanted to take a moment and toast with praise (or champagne if you just happen to have a glass) some of the delegates from 2004 (and a very cheerful 2005 lady) that have stayed in touch, although you will remain nameless, you know who you are, lil' missy's. My praise is not because you have "stayed in touch", (because this would apply to a lot of you, too) but because you are every thing that I admire..., ...while staying in touch.
    I admire your integrity and that you share generously your enthusiasm; praise, good thoughts and words of fellow delegates and of the Globe system.
    Iron sharpens iron, and good begets good.
    Oh sure I have a crown and a banner somewhere in my house, as do you, but it is those who have cast their crown and ambition aside, or even, to cast ambition for a crown aside to elevate and esteem a fellow delegate.
    Not only have you impelled me with your thoughtfulness and edification, but you built up other women, who may in fact never know the amazing and kind things I've heard from you.
    So thank you, and once again I am just delighted to be with you all for another year!
    Cheers!
    Kay
    Mrs.Byrd
    (AKA Colorado)

  • Christmas for Kids and A Smile for the New Year! -- Monica Ulrich, 17:00:46 10/11/04 Mon [1]
    As the holidays are rapidly approaching, we are planning our holiday outreach for this year. Seeing as our newly crowned Mrs. Globe, Rumiana, is from Bulgaria, we have chosen a childrens orphanage to support. The orphanage is called Katia Vancheva, has 60 children from the ages of newborn to 12 years old living there, and is located in Sofia, Bulgaria.

    Here is how it will work: Tracy and I will be traveling to Bulgaria from December 15th to 20th and will host Christmas for these children, along with Rumiana. We are looking for 60-people to adopt a child & provide a gift package & have it delivered to our office by December 1st, this way we can ship the packages to Bulgaria to arrive in time. In addition, we are asking for small monetary donation ($50 to $100) to cover the shipping fees. If you are interested in providing a gift, please contact me directly and I will give you the name/age/sex of the child, this way you may personalize the gift.

    Please contact me directly if you are interested in traveling to Bulgaria, I will let you know what the fees involved are at this point in time.

    Thanks!
    Monica

  • Greeting to everyone! -- Linda "Di"Giacomo, 06:08:18 10/06/04 Wed [1]
    Hello everyone! I just wanted to post a quick note and say that I am very excited about being part of the Mrs. Globe family!

    It was such a heartwarming feeling to see emails from a few of my Mrs. Globe sisters who DON'T EVEN KNOW ME, checking in on how I was doing after 4 hurricanes here in the Sunshine State (now lovingly dubbed the "Plywood State"! hehe!!). Even with some damage, I consider myself very fortunate compared to how other areas faired through the storms. I am grateful for what I have and for my family that mean so much to me. It's amazing how quickly you can take everyday necesities for granted.

    Just something to share: one of my favorite music groups, "Point of Grace" (Grace is the meaning of my middle name), performs a song called, "Keep the Candle Burning". They chorus goes as such:

    "When you're walking in the dead of night, and your soul is turning. When your hope seems out of sight, keep the candle burning. All it takes is one steady heart, in a world that turning. Shine THE light (meaning Christ) and pierce the dark, keep the candle burning. Keep the candle burning!"

    This has been a wonderful message of hope for me in trials and tribulations. Just keep your eyes and heart focused on our Lord and his light with pierce and destroy the darkness we tend to let ourselves sink into when the roads get tough!!!

    My love and best to you ALL!! I cannot wait to physically meet my new sisters at the Mrs. US Globe Pageant next July!! Take care and we'll be talking!!

    Linda "Di" :)
    Mrs. Florida 2005

  • A laugh (at least for me) -- Tia Hunsperger, 17:44:55 09/18/04 Sat [1]
    Sometimes my family teases me because I am the only one who thinks my stories are funny. I had this thought the other day and I thought some of you might enjoy it as well. I was at my husbands Soccer game the other night and was thinking about how Soccer relates to pageants. There was a player who got a yellow card. For those of you who are not soccer players, moms(I guess in my case wives) or fans, a yellow card is given by the ref when a player does something out of line and the person must stay off the field for a given amount of time. When a red card)given for a much worse or multiple infraction) is given you are out of the game. I sometimes multitask and walk laps around the field while the game is going on. There was this play that happened really close to me a player was given a red card. Scot asked the ref what the card was given for and he explained and then Scot said... so that is what you saw. I thought about the right living class on perception. What the ref saw from the other side of the field was very different than what I saw right in front of me.
    Ok so the funny part was I thought about if we could give out Red and yellow cards during pageant week. Wouldn't that be funny if when somebody got grumpy, a hand would go flying up with a card! HE HE!
    I hope you all are doing well!

  • WIN to be a recipient -- Monica Ulrich, DoM, 11:12:59 09/01/04 Wed [1]
    We have very exciting news to share with you! In pursuit of new swimsuit sponsors earlier this year, I contacted Ujeana swimwear to see if they would like to sponsor swimsuits for the pageant. Unfortunately they were unable to do so this year, but after reading our information that we provide sponsors, Ujeana loved W.I.N. and wanted to help in some way. Little did we know that as we at the national office were speaking to Ujeana, that Tia hunsberger, Mrs. Washington 2003/04 was also sharing about WIN and Mrs. Globe to another swimsuit designer in Seattle, WA. Tia immediately called me and asked that I get in touch with her contact. Much to our surprise, both swimsuit designers were already involved with a non-profit organization in NY, called Faces of Change. This organization is launching a 2005/06 calendar for charity. They have selected various charity's that the calendar will benefit, WIN being one of them! The calendar has been sold into Barnes & Nobles bookstores, amongst various other locations around the world! I do not have the details as of yet, but will send the price and where you can buy your calendar in November.

    For more information on the organization, please log on to their website and feel free to leave a message on their message board about WIN! The more comments their website gets, the more exposure WIN gets, which in turn helps us, help those in need. The website is: www.facesofchange.org You may click on "The Charities" and will see a link to WIN on the third line.

A collection of classical and familiar melodies performed by Whit Kellogg for children five to eight years old. This compact disc is designed for a class taught by Stephanie Marini and includes floor work, barre work, center work and creative movement. Wonderful music for the moods of being angry, happy, hurt and triumphant along with expressive songs like Flight Of The Bumble Bee and Hi Ho Hi Ho are included on this compact disc. Each selection is extra long to accommodate several groups of dancers.   This compact disc contains great music for dancers returning to tap. Each compact disc is designed for a complete ballet class with long bands of solo piano music for each side at the Barre or long combinations in the center. After the success of my first CD of this genre, Ballet Elite, I felt the time was right for another. Ballet Fantastique is the fruit of two months of intensive work and years of experience in the ballet studio. Once again, all the pieces started life as improvisations during class. They all get elaborated upon as time goes by and I start to get ideas for orchestrations as they develop. I end up with a tough job in selecting the pieces for the project. Then the fun part: orderstrating the music begins. The final result is sure to give your ballet classes a musical lift, and serve as an inspiration to everyone in the studio.
........MUSIC........
