Refining of Complete Antibody Structure Represents Milestone in Biology

To rid the body of foreign invaders such as viruses and bacteria, the body musters an army of antibodies -- flexible proteins that take on various shapes to recognize and eliminate the invaders. Knowing the structure of antibody proteins also helps researchers design drug therapies for diseases, including some forms of cancer. Until recently, however, scientists had never solved the complete structure of an antibody molecule.

This fundamental milestone for immunology, biochemistry, biology, and medicine was achieved by Lisa Harris, Steven Larson, Karl Hasel, and Alexander McPherson of the University of California, Riverside, with the structure of an antibody, called IgG2a, that binds to and eliminates cancerous white blood cells in dogs. With X-ray diffraction data on the crystallized form of the antibody, the researchers used SDSC's CRAY C90 and the MERLOT and X-PLOR software packages to determine the entire 3-D structure of the antibody at a detail far greater than previously available.

"This structure has great implications for increasing biomedical knowledge," said Lisa Harris of McPherson's lab. "This is the first 3-D visualization of an entire antibody molecule at the atomic level using X-ray crystallographic techniques." Harris and McPherson have also recently used SDSC's TeleManufacturing Facility to create a solid model of the antibody, magnified several million times.

The entire antibody includes two antigen binding segments (Fabs) connected to the Fc segment of the molecule by hinge polypeptides. The hinge region confers flexibility to the molecule, which is vital to its function.

Many fragments of antibodies (such as an Fab, Fc, or Fv) have been solved in the past by other investigators. Two antibodies with "deleted" hinges were also previously determined, and a third antibody with a normal hinge was studied but only a partial structure resulted (the Fc could not be seen). This IgG2a structure represents the first, complete antibody structure where all segments are visible.

"We have recently solved a second whole antibody as well, an IgG1 antibody," Harris said. "These results describe one of the most basic molecules of the immune system, which is fundamental to immunology, biochemistry, biology, and medicine."

These results have appeared in the journals Nature and Biochemistry, as well as being invited to appear in a number of textbooks, about 20 so far. The information, in particular, may help improve chemotherapy techniques for canine lymphoma. This disease is an animal model for a human cancer, non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, and could serve as an intermediate step for improving the treatments available to human lymphoma patients.

For more information see:

  1. Harris, L.J., Larson, S.B., Hasel, K.W. & McPherson, A. (1997) Refined structure of an intact IgG2a monoclonal antibody. Biochemistry, 36, 1581-1597.
  2. Harris, L.J., Larson, S.B., Hasel, K.W., Day, J., Greenwood, A. & McPherson, A. (1992) The three-dimensional structure of an intact monoclonal antibody for canine lymphoma. Nature, 360, 369-372.
  3. Harris, L.J., Skaletsky, E. & McPherson, A. (1995) Crystallization of intact monoclonal antibodies. Proteins, 23, 285-289.

Lisa Harris ifets-discussion <IFETS-DISCUSSION@COMPUTER.ORG>
Mon, 25 Aug 2003 14:06:05 +1000

  • Previous message: [Ifets] [IFETS-DISCUSS] IFETS education for all discussion
  • Next message: [Ifets] [IFETS-DISCUSS] Pre-discussion paper - An Initial Experiment For Attaining Education For All
  • Messages sorted by: [ date ] [ thread ] [ subject ] [ author ] 
Dear All,

Sorry for the delay in contributing to this discussion, but I thought I
would throw this in anyway.  I am a avid technology user, I have a laptop
and Sony Clie (Palm like device) and I receive most of my academic materials
and correspondence electronically.  I am currently doing a PhD and the use
of electronic materials have been invaluable for their ease of access and
the capacity to have everything open at once while I am writing.  However,
there is one point that I haven't seen so far and that is the cost of
electronic devices.  While I may store everything electronically I am still
likely to print out a copy of the latest article I have found and take it
down the local cafe to read and make notes.  That way I have no worries if I
leave it in the car to go shopping, cram it in the bottom of my backpack
when I am stuffing groceries in my bag, etc.  Meanwhile my laptop and to
some extent my Sony Clie either remain safely at home or else are treated
with extreme care.  For the most part electronic devices are still expensive
and are really not robust enough to throw around like we do paper.  I agree
with many that this shouldn't be an either or discussion, and that over time
we will become more and more accustom to reading on screens - the point for
me is that at $500 - $1000 AUD for the cheapest type of electronic device, I
will continue to look forward to accessing information electronically (with
all the search and hyperlink facilities) and then printing things out to
take to the beach or local cafes, etc to read.

regards...Lisa

Lisa Harris
Coordinator of Teaching
School of Social Science and Planning RMIT University,

Lend Us a Hand!

  

 

Click on the pics for larger images

Lisa Harris organized this fun meet, which had approximately 18 RADP'ers gathering early one Sunday morning in the Magic Kingdom.

First Row (kneeling): David Luner, Robin Beal, Barbara Bennett, Kenny Rudd, Rich Pearlstein.
Second Row: Mike Henigan, Gene and Aven Baral, Randy B., Allan Bennett, Brian Bennett, Katrin.
Back Row: Wayne and Jennifer Geer, Chet Polo, Beth Bieber, Lisa Harris, Carol DiPace, Deb Wills

When I arrived, Brian Bennett and family and Rich Pearlstein were already engaged in an intense Disney discussion. Quickly, people made their way to the Partners Statue and found this wide eyed group of radp'ers awaiting the rope drop! We had to look for a while, but did manage to find a CM (Thank you Adam! who actually knew about RADP) who was willing to take photos with about 10 cameras!

As we all listened to the Magic Kingdom open for the day, we quickly headed through Adventureland and over to the Mountain Ranges. Folks were loosing site of Lisa, who was walking quickly, so I loaned her my CANAM RADP meet hat to hold high in the air for us to follow.

Boat Number 1 included: (Front to back, left to right): Randy B. and Lisa Harris, Chet Polo and Beth Bieber, David Luner and Robin Beal, , Katrin Haussmann and Brian Bennett.

It didn't take but about 10 minutes in line before 16 radp'ers filled 2 complete boats on a visiting to my Laughing Place!

Boat Number 2 included: (Front to back, left to right): Rich Pearlstein and Kenny Rudd, Aven and Gene Baral, Deb Wills and Carol DiPace, Wayne and Jennifer.

While everyone wanted to GO AGAIN....we thought it best to keep moving (it was a little cool and we got a little WET!). Brian Bennett and Rich Pearlstein left at this point and off to Big Thunder Mountain Railroad we went.

A way cool ride on BTMRR left many of us wanting more thrills.
